These revisions do not include the portion of the rules for nonattainment areas as there are currently no nonattainment areas in the state of Iowa. The definitions and applicability portions of the Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) program were written into the state rules while the remaining portions of the PSD program were adopted by reference. All references to clean units and pollution control projects are not adopted by reference. Iowa has also not adopted portions of the Federal rule relating to exceptions from recordkeeping requirements. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, SOx, VOC. This rule is effective on 6/13/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Iowa; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Iowa SIP submitted on 8/15/2006. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA is proposing to determine that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Iowa. Thus, as a consequence of the SIP approval, EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, NOx ozone season emissions for Iowa. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes state budgets for SO2 and NOx and requires states to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets in states that EPA concluded did contribute to nonattainment in downwind states. States have the flexibility to choose which control measures to adopt to achieve the budgets, including participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs. Comments must be received on or before 6/7/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the Nevada state implementation plan, Washoe County
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Washoe County portion of the Nevada SIP, which concern particulate matter emissions from fugitive dust sources, such as open areas, unpaved roads, and construction activities. The agency is approving this local rule that regulates these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. This rule is effective on 7/9/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 6/7/2007. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, particulate matter, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Supplemental notice of proposed rulemaking for prevention of significant deterioration and nonattainment new source review: Emission increases for electric generating units; proposed rule
Abstract: This action is a supplemental notice of proposed rulemaking (SNPR) to EPA's 10/20/2005 notice of proposed rulemaking (NPR). In the October 2005 NPR, EPA proposed to revise the emissions test for existing electric generating units (EGU) that are subject to the regulations governing the Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) and nonattainment major New Source Review (NSR) programs mandated by parts C and D of title I of the Clean Air Act (CAA). EPA proposed three alternatives for the emissions test: a maximum achievable hourly emissions test, a maximum achieved hourly emissions test, and an output-based hourly emissions test. This action recasts the proposed options so that the output-based test becomes an alternative method to implement the maximum achieved or maximum achievable hourly tests, rather than a separate option. These proposed regulations interpret the emissions increase component of the modification test under CAA 111(a)(4), in the context of NSR, for existing EGU. The proposed regulations would promote the safety, reliability, and efficiency of EGU. Each IPM model run is based on emissions controls on existing units, state regulations, cost and performance of generating technologies, SO2 and NOx heat rates, natural gas supply and prices, and electricity demand growth assumptions. Comments must be received on or before 7/9/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The world this week: Rhodia and total pay for acid gas clean ups in US
Abstract: Rhodia has agreed to spend $50 million to cut emissions from eight sulfuric acid plants in four US states. It will also pay a $2 million fine to settle violations of the Clean Air Act. The investment is expected to reduce emissions of SO2 by 19,000 ton/yr. Separately, Total Petrochemicals is paying a $3 million fine and spending $37 million at its Port Arthur, TX, refinery, to cut emissions of NOx and SO2.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Darned if you do, darned if you don't
Abstract: The Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights (FTCR) has set up an offensive situation, in which any bad act done by the oil and gas company would get unnoticed and unpunished. Any internal act such as CO2 sequestration, educational, agricultural and industrial improvement programs in countries in which they work, voluntary cleanup programs by oil industry employees, self-imposed carbon dioxide reduction programs, and grants to local communities for hundreds of charitable reason would not count. The FTCR could berate the industry for not doing anything to protect the environment, if oil and gas companies stopped their contributions to universities and educational and environmental programs.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: What's new...: Piercing tools, pipe bursting-ramming, directional drilling rigs, locating systems and vacuum excavation: Mustang engineering
Abstract: Mustang Engineering and John Wood Group have been awarded US patent 715 5917 for a proprietary process to convert LNG into natural gas. Described as environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient technology and marketed as the LNG Smart® Air Vaporization (SAV) process, it uses a closed-loop intermediate fluid circulating through fin-fan heat exchangers to extract heat from ambient air to vaporize LNG from its cryogenic state at - 260°F back to pipeline temperatures for transporting and storage. The SAV technology provides major reductions in fugitive air emissions (up to 100% under certain ambient conditions), and substantially lowers facility operating costs (through significantly reduced fuel gas usage).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 2007 Minnesota Legislature
Abstract: The 2007 session of the Minnesota Legislature was highly productive for TPA members and the forestry community as major funding increases were passed for forestry and timber sale programs. The legislature also extended the Sustainable Forest Resources Act for another 10 years and preserved forest road exemptions in the Wetlands Conservation Act. The Legislature passed a major energy legislation mandating an increase in the use of renewable power and establishing targets for reductions in greenhouse gases. A legislation that would require an economic impact statement if state forestlands are withdrawn from management was introduced. The session also presented a provision to make the truck corridor from Grand Rapids to Duluth operational was included in the Omnibus Transportation Policy Conference Report.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Carbon tax vs. cap-and-trade
Abstract: Several states and groups of states in America took efforts to implement regulations in the absence of federal action, and introduce effective legislation for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. For each of these initiatives, the only mechanism being considered for governing greenhouse gas emissions, particularly CO2, is a cap-and-trade approach. There are ways to reduce CO2 emissions, such as Command-and control approaches, which would dictate the use of specific technology to cut CO 2emissions and limit flexibility. Taxation is an effective way to reduce CO2 emission, and this provide advantages including ease of implementation, broad applicability, and economic impacts. Both a carbon tax and a cap-and-trade system would result in higher energy costs to consumers, and carbon tax approaches are effectively designed such that tax revenues are returned to the public in the form of reduced payroll or sales taxes.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Futtsu - TEPCO's power city
Abstract: Tokyo Electric Power Company's (TEPCO) Futtsu Thermal Power Station at Japan is a combined-cycle power plant, which has planned to install GE 9H gas turbines by July 2010 to deliver 5040 MW combined-cycle power. The installation of gas turbines is aimed to meet the reliability, operability, efficiency, and maintenance requirements of the Futtsu Thermal Power Station. The gas turbines lowers variable costs for the customers and reduces environmental emission per unit electricity. The unique design feature of 9H includes inlet air configuration, which brings inlet air to the gas turbine compressor. Futtsu Station aims to meet electricity production demand and become a powerful fuel supply base for thermal power plants in Japan by installing the 9H gas turbines and construction of new fuel storage tanks.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Water taxis to run on hydrogen gas
Abstract: The Brightwell Group, an investment company with offices in The Netherlands, Turkey and the USA, is representing Turkish boatbuilder Labranda in putting a United Nations-funded initiative aimed at putting Turkish-built hydrogen-powered water taxis into use in various locations in the Mediterranean and Middle East. Under the umbrella of the United Nations Industrial Development Organizations and International Center for Hydrogen Energy Technologies (UNIDO-ICHET), the 10.9m catamaran-hulled water taxis are designed to carry maximum of 10 passengers, making use of waterways in and around coastal town in Turkey, UAE, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Greece. The US-based Hydrogen Engine Center (HEC) signed a letter for the supply of 200 HEC's alternative-fueled marine engines project. The existing alternative-fuel engine will be based on a new 7.5liter V8 spark-ignition engine that are designed for operation using hydrogen fuel and/or compressed natural gas (CNG). Fuels such as hydrogen burn zero carbon emission as well reduce dependence on volatile supplies of oil.
Index Keywords: Ferry boats; Hulls (ship); Hydrogen fuels; Inland waterways; Marine engines; Shipbuilding

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Materials: Soy-based resin
Abstract: A group from the United States Army Research Laboratory have developed a soy-based resin for fiber reinforced plastics (FRPs). The resultant resin performs equal to, or better, than petroleum-based counterparts as well as reduces styrene emissions by 20-78%. The bio-based FRPs have a wide range of military and civilian applications.
Index Keywords: fiber reinforced composite; plastic; polystyrene; synthetic resin

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Investment in a growing market
Abstract: The Kyoto Protocol has provided a stimulus to unlock forestry investment in developing countries. The United Nations Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) has begun granting Certified Emissions Reductions (CERs) to projects that have a net positive impact on atmospheric greenhouse gas levels. This means that reforestation projects in developing countries can earn additional revenues making them potentially more profitable. Forestry projects can generate CERs because trees absorb CO2 as they grow. Under CEM rules forestry projects are granted temporary or long-term CERs, in recognition of the non-permanent effect of carbon sequestration through forestry. Meanwhile, Carbon Capital is a company that provides finance for carbon reduction projects in the developing world. Carbon Capital has recently signed a deal with the government of Honghe State in Yunnan Province, China which has granted a 50 year renewable lease over 266,000 hectares near the Vietnamese border under a profit-sharing arrangement.
Index Keywords: clean development mechanism; developing world; economic instrument; emission control; Kyoto Protocol; Asia; China; Eurasia; Far East; Yunnan

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Change in deadline for rulemaking to address the control of emissions from new marine compression-ignition engines at or above 30 liters per cylinder
Abstract: A January 2003 final rule established the first US emission standards for new compression-ignition Category 3 marine engines, those with a displacement at or above 30 L/cylinder displacement. It also established a deadline of 4/27/2007 for EPA to promulgate a new tier of emission standards for these engines as determined appropriate under Clean Air Act section 213(a). This rulemaking schedule was intended to allow EPA time to consider the state of technology that may permit deeper emission reductions and the status of international action for more stringent standards. Due to the length of time necessary to assess advanced emission control technologies much of the information that EPA believes is necessary to develop more stringent Category 3 marine diesel engines standards has only become available recently and EPA expects more information to come to light in the course of the current negotiations underway at the IMO. Therefore, EPA is adopting a new deadline for the rulemaking that will consider the next tier of Category 3 marine diesel engine standards. Under this new schedule, EPA would adopt a final rule by 12/17/2009. This rule is effective on 6/26/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 5/29/2007 or a request for a public hearing by 5/17/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Ohio; Approval of revision to rescind portions of the Ohio transportation conformity regulations
Abstract: EPA is approving a 1/31/2007 request from Ohio for a SIP revision of the State transportation conformity regulations. Ohio held a public hearing on these revisions on 9/21/2006. These revisions rescind the portion of the state transportation conformity regulations which are no longer consistent with the Federal transportation conformity regulations. The rescission of the State regulations will allow the Federal transportation conformity regulations to govern transportation conformity determinations in Ohio. The subjects listed in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, intergovernmental relations, NO2, O3, and particulate matter. This direct final rule will be effective on 6/26/2007, unless EPA receives written adverse comments by 5/29/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; New Mexico; Albuquerque/Bernalillo County; Prevention of significant deterioration (PSD) and new source
Abstract: The EPA is approving revisions to the SIP for the Albuquerque/Bernalillo County, NM, area that were adopted on 12/14/2005, and submitted to EPA by the Governor of New Mexico on 5/24/2006. The SIP revisions modify the PSD and Nonattainment New Source Review (NNSR) regulations in the SIP. They were submitted to make the area's PSD and NNSR rules consistent with the Federal PSD and NNSR revised regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002, (67 FR 80186), and reconsidered with minor changes on 11/7/2003, (68 FR 63021). The revisions include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected-actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plant-wide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. The EPA is approving these revisions pursuant to section 110, part C, and part D of the Federal Clean Air Act. This final rule is effective on 5/29/2007. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, intergovernmental relations, lead, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Utah; State implementation plan corrections
Abstract: When EPA approved Utahs Rule Recodification on 2/14/2006, they inadvertently incorporated by reference rules into the SIP. When EPA approved Utahs Continuous Emission Monitoring Program on 5/15/2003, they inadvertently failed to remove the older version of the Continuous Emission Monitoring Program rule from the SIP. When EPA approved Revisions to the Utah Administrative Code on 11/1/2006, they inadvertently incorporated by reference incorrect state rules. Finally, when EPA approved CO provisions for Provo, they inadvertently failed to remove the older version of Control Measures For Area and Point Sources CO Provo. EPA is correcting these errors with this document. This rule is effective on 5/18/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Notice Pursuant to the National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993-Testing of Methods for Measuring Hydrocarbon Dew Points in Natural Gas Streams
Abstract: Notice is hereby given that, on 3/20/2007, pursuant to Section 6(a) of the National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993, 15 U.S.C. 4301 et seq., Southwest Research Institute (SwRI) has filed written notifications simultaneously with the Attorney General and the Federal Trade Commission disclosing the identities of the parties to the venture and the nature and objectives of the venture. The notifications were filed to invoke the Acts provisions limiting the recovery of antitrust plaintiffs to actual damages under specified circumstances. Pursuant to Section 6(b) of the Act, the identities of the parties to the venture are: Ametek/Process & Analytical, Pittsburgh, PA; Gas Processors Association, Tulsa, OK; Michell Instruments Inc, Danbury, CT; and Pipeline Research Council International, Inc, Arlington, VA. The general area of SwRI's planned activity is to evaluate existing instruments to objectively measure hydrocarbon dew points in natural gas. Emphasis will be placed on accuracy, repeatability, and response time of hydrocarbon dew point measurements. This project is proposed to resolve technical issues associated with the determination of natural gas quality by the industry. Membership in this research group remains open, and the participants intend to file additional written notification disclosing all changes in membership or planned activities.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Arkansas; prevention of significant deterioration and new source review; economic development zone for Crittenden County, AR; and stage 1 vapor recovery
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Arkansas SIP that include changes made to Arkansas regulations entitled, Regulations of the Arkansas Plan of Implementation for Air Pollution Control and Nonattainment New Source Review Requirements. The revisions amend the State's permitting rules in order to address revisions to the Federal New Source Review (NSR) regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002 and reconsidered with minor changes on 11/7/2003. Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment NSR programs, together with the minor preconstruction permit program required by the Federal Clean Air Act, are commonly referred to as the NSR programs. Arkansas revised its preconstruction permitting rules that affect major sources and major modifications to include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected- actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plant-wide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. The revisions also include non-substantive revisions to previously SIP-approved regulations and new regulations for implementing the permitting provisions for the 8-hr ozone NAAQS-Phase 2, Economic Development Zone in Crittenden County, and Stage I Vapor Recovery. EPA is taking no action on provisions that relate to designated facilities. This final rule is effective on 5/14/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: General interest: Supreme Court gives EPA authority to limit CO2 emissions
Abstract: The US Supreme Court ruled that the EPA has the authority, under the Clean Air Act, to enact limits on CO2 emissions. The lawsuit was filed by Massachusetts along with several other states, US cities, and environmental groups. EPA has statutory to regulate emissions of gases from new motor vehicles because greenhouse gases fit well within the act's capacious definition of air pollutant. The statutory question is whether sufficient information exists to make an endangerment finding.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Supreme Court gives EPA authority to limit CO2 emissions
Abstract: The US Supreme Court ruled out April 2 that the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has the authority, under the Clean Air Act, to enact limits on carbon dioxide emissions. The lawsuit was filed by Massachusetts along with several other states and environmental groups. The argue that because greenhouse gases fit well within the act's capacious definition of air pollutant, EPA has statutory authority to regulate emissions of such gases from new motor vehicles. The question is whether sufficient information exists to make an endangerment finding. In addition, there are questions as to what levels of CO2, if any, are to be allowed without being considered to be pollutants.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Emission control; Gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; Laws and legislation; Public policy; atmospheric pollution; carbon dioxide; carbon emission; environmental protection; greenhouse effect; North America; United States

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Record of decision, Orlando gasification project, Orlando, Orange County, FL
Abstract: The DOE has prepared an environmental impact statement (EIS) (DOE/EIS0383) to assess the environmental impacts associated with a proposed project that would be cost-shared by DOE and Southern Co (in partnership with the Orlando Utilities Commission) (OUC) under DOE's Clean Coal Power Initiative program. The project would demonstrate advanced power generation systems using Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) technology at OUC's existing Stanton Energy Center near Orlando, FL. The IGCC facilities would substantially reduce emissions of SO2, NOx, and mercury relative to existing, conventional coal-fired power plants. After careful consideration of the potential environmental impacts, along with program goals and objectives, DOE has decided that it will provide, through a cooperative agreement with Southern Co, a total of $235 million in cost-shared funding (about 41% of the total cost of ≈ $569 million) to design, construct, and demonstrate the Orlando Gasification Project proposed by Southern Co.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: Canada: The Alberta government, which regulates 80%...
Abstract: The Alberta government will introduce legislation from July 2007 requiring the province's 100 largest industrial facilities, which each release > 100,000 ton/yr of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, to reduce those GHG levels by 12% per unit of production. Companies unable to meet the quota will either pay $(Can)15/ton into a technology fund to develop ways of lowering GHG emissions, or buy carbon credits from Alberta-based companies that achieve the target. According to the Canadian Association of Petroleum producers, the legislation will cost oil and gas producers hundreds of millions of dollars a year.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Business update: Small businesses: Big payoffs in new technologies for America
Abstract: The EPA announced $2.52 million in contracts to 36 small businesses in 22 states to develop new technologies that will protect human health and the environment. Given under EPA's Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program, the projects will focus on 14 key environmental areas, including protecting the Great Lakes; improving air quality; managing wastewater; finding innovations in manufacturing for environmental protection; protecting the environment using nanotechnology; reducing engine and vehicle emissions; and developing new methods to produce biodiesel, butanol and ethanol. EPA will again be requesting applications for the development of new environmental technologies from 3/15/2007 to 5/23/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Arizona; motor vehicle inspection and maintenance programs
Abstract: EPA is approving two revisions to the Arizona SIP submitted by the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality. These revisions consist of: changes to Arizona's Basic and Enhanced Vehicle Emissions Inspection Programs to exempt collectible vehicles in the Phoenix metropolitan area, and collectible vehicles and motorcycles in the Tucson metropolitan area, from emissions testing requirements; an updated performance standard evaluation for the vehicle emissions inspection program in the Phoenix area; and new contingency measures. EPA is approving these two SIP revisions because they meet all applicable requirements of the Clean Air Act and EPA's regulations and because the exemptions will not interfere with attainment or maintenance of the NAAQS in the two affected areas. EPA is finalizing this action under the Clean Air Act obligation to take action on State submittals of revisions to SIP. The intended effect is to exempt these vehicle categories from the emissions testing requirements of the State's vehicle emissions inspection programs as approved for the Phoenix and Tucson areas but also to provide a mechanism to reinstate the requirements in the event of a violation of the CO NAAQS in the Phoenix or Tucson area. This rule is effective on 4/30/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Ohio; control of gasoline volatility
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a SIP revision submitted by the State of Ohio on 2/14/2006 and 10/6/2006, establishing a lower Rvp fuel requirement for gasoline distributed in the Cincinnati and Dayton 8-hr ozone nonattainmentareas. Ohio has developed these fuel requirements to reduce emissions of VOC in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act (CAA). EPA is proposing to approve Ohio's fuel requirements into the Ohio SIP because EPA has found that the requirements are necessary for the Cincinnati and Dayton areas to achieve the 8-hr ozone NAAQS. This action is being taken under section 110 of the CAA. Comments must be received on or before 4/30/2007. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, intergovernmental relations, NO2, ozone, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Panel market report
Abstract: Some of the recent trends in the lumber market as on March 23, 2007 are discussed. Market for the OSB in South and western deliverd regions showed the most spark. Prices also showed modest increases in Mid-Atlantic region. Producers in the North Central region and Eastern Canada sold much of their output in the West. Cuts in prices were limited as producers circled the wagons, citing higher veneer costs. Fir prices compared to Southern Pine plywood sparked orders, including some from Texas and the southeast. Shortage of the raw materials constrained industrial particleboard production and created uncertainity about near term supplies, espcially in the West. MDF sales were steady brisk. Proposed regulations associated with formaldehyde emissions outlined at the California Air Resources board were widely discussed among trader.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New Jersey; Low emission vehicle program
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a New Jersey SIP revision that adopts California's second generation low emission vehicle program for light-duty vehicles, LEV II. Clean Air Act section 177 sets forth requirements by which other states may adopt new motor vehicle emissions standards that are identical to Californias standards. Specifically, the States implementation plan revision adopts changes to its existing light duty vehicle rule by incorporating Californias LEV II program. The intended effect of this action is to approve, as consistent with section 110(a)(2) of the Clean Air Act, a control strategy that will help New Jersey achieve attainment of the NAAQS for ozone. Comments must be received on or before 4/20/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Aprroval and promulgation of implementation plans; Implementation plan revision; State of New Jersey
Abstract: EPA proposes to approve a request from the State of New Jersey to revise its SIP for ozone to incorporate state-adopted amendments to Subchapter 19 "Control and Prohibition of Air Pollution from Oxides of Nitrogen" and related amendments to Subchapter 16 "Control and Prohibition of Air Pollution by Volatile Organic Compounds". The amendments relate to the control of NOx emissions from stationary industrial sources, e.g., natural gas fired industrial/commercial/institutional boilers. This SIP revision consists of control measures needed to meet the shortfall in emission reductions in New Jersey's 1-hr ozone attainment demonstration SIP as identified by EPA. The intended effect of this proposed rule is to approve the state control strategy, which will result in emission reductions that will help achieve attainment of the NAAQS for ozone required by the Clean Air Act. Comments must be received on or before 4/13/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implemetation plans; Revisions to the Nevada state implementation plan; Visible emissions and pariculate matter rules
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Nevada Department of Conservation and Natural Resources portion of the Nevada SIP, which concern visible emissions and particulate matter regulations, e.g., the Sunrise power plant that normally runs on natural gas. EPA is proposing this action under the Clean Air Act obligation to take action on State submittals of revisions to SIP. The intended effect is to approve updated visible emissions and particulate matter rules in the Nevada SIP because doing so will not interfere with attainment or maintenance of the NAAQS or any other requirement of the Clean Air Act. EPA is taking comments on this proposal and plans to follow with a final action. Comments must arrive by 4/11/2007. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, intergovernmental relations, particulate matter, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Improving internal combustion
Abstract: Researchers have created the first computational model to track engine performance from one combustion cycle to the next for a new type of engine that can reduce oil consumption and the emission of global-warming pollutants. The concept, known as variable valve actuation, will enable significant improvements in conventional gasoline and diesel engines used in cars and trucks and for applications such as generators. The technique also enables the introduction of an advanced method called homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI), which will allow the United States to reduce its dependence on foreign oil and production of harmful exhaust emissions. The HCCI technique will make it possible to improve the efficiency of gasoline engines by 15 per cent to 20 per cent, making them as efficient as diesel engines, while eliminating smog-generating nitrogen oxides. The improved combustion efficiency also will reduce emission of two other harmful gases contained in exhaust.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Keeping toronto cool
Abstract: The advantages and features of the Deep Lake Water Cooling (DLWC) system in Toronto are discussed. The DLWC system is operated by Enwave Energy Corporation, a private corporation co-owned by the City of Toronto and the Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System (OMERS). The DLWC system has enough capacity to air condition 100 office buildings or 34 million square feet of building space. The system also reduces the greenhouse gases and also eliminates the use of large quantities of ozone-depleting refrigerants. Centralized production of cooling energy is more cost-effective, reliable and convenient than distributed building-specific cooling as it removes the need to acquire, service and maintain cooling equipment in each building. Enwave is connecting DLWC customers to its distribution loop at the rate of about 18 new buildings per year.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Health safety & the environment: Alberta first province to legislate greenhouse gas reductions
Abstract: In early March 2007, Alberta Premier Ed Stelmach introduced legislation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions intensity from large industry. Bill 3, Climate Change and Emissions Management Amendment Act and its accompanying Specified Gas Emitters Regulation state companies that emit > 100,000 ton/yr of greenhouse gases must reduce their emissions intensity by 12% starting 7/1/2007. The Specified Gas Emitters Regulation details how companies can reduce their emissions intensity. Emissions can be measured against: barrels of oil; per million cubic feet of natural gas; per ton of coal; and per megawatt hour of electricity. It is expected the regulation will apply to about 100 facilities that represent about 70% of Alberta's industrial emissions. If reducing emissions intensity by 12% is not initially possible, large emitters will be able to invest in an Alberta-based technology fund.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Sustainability - 2010 'green' Olympics, BC energy plan and coalbed methane
Abstract: Richard Neufeld, the Minister of energy, Mines, and Petroleum Resources, British Columbia, has revealed the new British Columbia (BC) Energy Plan, which is considered a vision for Clean Energy Leadership. The new Energy Plan puts BC at the edge with aggressive targets for zero net greenhouse gas emissions, new investments, in innovation and an ambitious target to acquire 50 percent of BC Hydro's incremental resource that needs thorough conservation by the year 2020. This plan includes conventional oil and gas, considers all forms of clean, alternative energy in meeting British Columbians' needs in the provincial economy, and all potential sources of clean and renewable energy, such as bioenergy, geothermal energy, tidal, run-of-river, solar, and wind power. The plan targets at ensuring zero net greenhouse gas emissions at major energy establishments, such as all new electricity projects developed in BC, existing thermal generation power plants, coal fired electricity generations.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Canada: Carbon capture pipeline could cost "up to $5bn"
Abstract: The proposed provincial plan in Alberta to pump and store industrial CO2 waste underground using a pipeline network could cost as much as $5 billion, the Province's Environment Minister Rob Renner suggested in mid-March 2007. In a joint news conference in Edmonton, Prime Minister Stephen Harper and Alberta Premier Ed Stelmach lauded the plan to capture CO2, something that is already being done with smaller projects on the Prairies. Mr. Harper called it dream that could truly change the world. Mr. Stelmach has set up a committee to look at the advantage, disadvantages, and costs of expanding the process to a large scale. According to Mr. Renner, the committee will also look at who would foot the bill for the pipeline, noting that if governments impose additional costs upon industry, those costs eventually will float down and be borne by the consumer. The carbon pipeline is one of a number of initiatives the province is considering to reduce greenhouse gases, with the help of a $156-million grant announced in March by Mr. Harper. Mr. Stelmach's provincial government has tabled legislation to force large-scale producers to cut their emissions intensity by 12%, starting on 7/1/2007. Those that do not meet targets have the option of paying into an eco-research fund at a cost of $15 for every ton they are in excess. According to the industry, this is nothing more than a carbon tax, and that it does not reward those who have already invested in green technology. Targeting emissions' intensity rather than emissions themselves has also been criticized. Emissions' intensity is the ratio of greenhouse gas per unit of output, and means that while emissions will not be able to grow as much as they have in the past, the total level will not necessarily decrease. In fact, it is claimed that a company could actually decrease its intensity ratio by increasing production.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industrial biotechnology policy agenda for Europe
Abstract: Industrial biotechnology (or, as known in Europe, white biotechnology) has the potential to form the basis of a future EU Knowledge-Based BioEconomy (KBBE) and make European society both more sustainable and more competitive. But to realize this potential, a number of policy steps must be taken. This report puts forward concrete policy proposals for the EU to encourage the development of a KBBE. Of primary importance is the need to develop policy coherently across the EU and to coordinate its implementation. There are many policy strands and activities which relate to biotechnology (e.g., biofuels, research and innovation, climate change, sustainable development, Common Agricultural Policy [CAP] reform, Environmental Technologies Action Plan [ETAP]); these must be harmonized for consistency and efficiency. Appointment of a KBBE coordinator by the Commission to bring together activities in the various Directorates General (DGs) is essential. At the same time, a KBBE task force is needed to coordinate EU member state programs. It is equally important that the policy be based on sound evidence. Data gathering, collation, and analysis underpin the whole process: Good policy cannot be formulated without good data. At the other end of the policy-making process, a comprehensive roadmap is needed to chart the way towards the biobased economy and allow both coherent implementation and good impact evaluation. With the enabling policy framework in place, full support then has to be given to innovation in biotechnology in general, and white biotechnology in particular. This is a research-driven activity, and Europe must build upon its strengths in the area. This means, in particular, ensuring that the various relevant Strategic Research Agendas (SRAs) from the KBBE-related Technology Platforms (particularly Sustainable Chemistry, Plants for the Future, Forestry, and Biofuels) are properly planned, funded, and implemented within the Framework 7 program and at member state level through, for instance, the European Research Area Network (ERA-Net). Within this context, it is important to foster the synergies among the various participating sectors, for example, by stimulating publicprivate partnership and industry participation in general, promoting interdisciplinary research, and striving to avoid fragmentation and duplication of programs. This cooperation must also extend downstream to demonstration projects, in particular, to enable the development of flexible, research-oriented pilot plants to validate the concept of integrated and diversified biorefineries. Appropriate funding schemes will be needed to allow multicompany consortia to collaborate in such precompetitive activities (first-of-kind biorefmeries). Moving beyond the research phase, there are practical steps which can be taken to facilitate the move towards bioprocessing in manufacturing. A necessary prerequisite is the assurance of a secure and affordable supply of biomass, for which a combination of policy, innovation, and financial incentives will be needed. With the supply of feedstock assured, conversion of existing industrial processes to biobased ones can be encouraged through streamlined regulatory processes (akin to the Fast Track system used by the US Environmental Protection Agency), assessing the opportunities for biobased processes and products to contribute and benefit from the EU's Climate Change Policy and providing market-based mechanisms to overcome investment hurdles. This manufacturing push can be further enhanced through market-pull effects. Demand can be raised in a number of ways: for example by setting appropriate public-sector procurement standards, short-term positive price discrimination, or promotional labeling of products (e.g., "biobased") . While all these actions will have a positive effect, they will be more effective if supported by a coherent communications plan to raise awareness of the potential of industrial biotechnology, the use of renewable resources, and the benefits the KBBE will bring. The plan should take account of all major stakeholders, including industry, policy makers, consumers, farmers, and the investment community, but early-stage (upstream) open engagement with the general public is particularly important. Smaller companies make up an important part of this relatively young biotechnology sector, and it is they who will provide much of the necessary innovation. Because of their early stage of development, there are a number of hurdles they find more difficult to overcome than larger companies do. Small-to-medium enterprises (SMEs) need help, in particular, to reduce the cost of intellectual property protection. Ultimately, a single European Community patent will provide the answer, but in the meantime, a specific SME application process is needed at the European Patent Office (EPO). Early-stage search costs could also be reduced by introducing a searchable database flagged for industrial biotechnology applications. While intellectual property forms the basis of innovation, finance is needed to derive value from it. Proof-of-concept work is often funded by grants for start-up companies, and SMEs could benefit from a similar grant system for work on environment-friendly technologies. More generally, greater awareness of the potential of the industrial biotechnology sector is needed among the investment community in order for funds to be made available more easily. The necessary communications program is a vital part of the overall stakeholder outreach effort. But this in itself will not be sufficient. Because of the particular difficulties of raising capital for SMEs, a new investment model will be needed which sits between loans and conventional private equity, to provide finance along with equitable risk sharing. As the industrial biotechnology sector becomes increasingly successful, venture capital will become more available. In conclusion, to establish a sustainable KBBE in Europe, efforts are needed: To establish a coherent European Policy Agenda for industrial biotechnology and the KBBE To stimulate and support innovation in plant science and industrial biotechnology To promote production and use of biobased products and processes To create awareness among all stakeholders To improve investment in KBBE-related SMEs.
Index Keywords: Biotechnology; Climate change; Innovation; Project management; Strategic planning; Sustainable development; Biotechnology policy; Policy-making; Publicprivate partnership; Industrial management; Biotechnology; Climate change; Industrial management; Innovation; Project management; Strategic planning; Sustainable development

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Emissions: Double exposure
Abstract: European Commission (EC) is making efforts to limit the aviation emissions, which is being forecasted to double by 2020. The EC has proposed a late 2006 working document that all intra EU flights should be included with effect from 2011 and this scope should be expanded from 2012 to cover all flights arriving at or departing from EU airports. The EC also proposed that instead of the national caps set for industrial emissions, aviation emissions should be capped at the average level for 2004-06 for the three trading periods until 2022. The European Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) relates only to carbon dioxide emissions from large, fixed, energy-intensive industrial installations across EU member states that account for almost half of the trading bloc's CO2 emissions. Member states draw up national allocation plans for each trading period determining the level of emission at national level, and distributing allowances.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry news: A new environmental coalition
Abstract: Ten major business operations have joined with four non-governmental organizations to call for action on carbon emissions, e.g., CO2. Called the United States Climate Action Partnership, the coalition includes businesses that run the gamut from manufacturing and energy to financial organizations. Business members include BP America, Duke Energy, DuPont, etc. The group of environmentally concerned organizations include the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Environmental Defense, etc. The group believes that business needs to get ahead of increasing political pressures to take action to avoid a confused mess of various state requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State's rules: California - Approved to limit small engine emissions
Abstract: California is requiring all small engines produced after 1/1/2007 to include catalytic converters in the exhaust system. The requirement is expected to reduce smog emissions from such sources by ≤ 40%. The cumulative effect of all these small engines is pegged at 7% of the state's total smog emissions, and is equivalent to emissions from over 3 million cars. The regulations cover engines that are < 50 hp in size, and would target lawnmowers, generators, and power washer units.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Downstream: Transport fuels from CTL process
Abstract: According to results of a new study by Energy Business Reports, road trials of coal-based fuels have shown that significant local air quality improvements can be realized through the reduction of tailpipe emissions. Particulate emissions can be ≤ 75% less than with traditional diesel, and NOx can be reduced by ≤ 60%. The optimization of new engines for these fuels will offer even greater reductions, particularly of NOx. New engine design, such as direct injection, will offer yet greater efficiencies.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New York; Motor vehicle enhanced inspection and maintenance program
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the SIP for New York's motor vehicle enhanced inspection and maintenance (I/M) program, which includes the adoption of a statewide On-Board Diagnostic program. New York has made revisions to Title 6 of the New York Codes, Rules and Regulations (NYCRR), Part 217, "Motor Vehicle Enhanced Inspection and Maintenance Program Requirements", and Title 15 NYCRR Part 79, "Motor Vehicle Inspection Regulations", to comply with EPA regulations and to improve performance of its I/M program. The intended effect of this action is to maintain consistency between the State-adopted rules and the federally approved SIP and to approve a control strategy that will result in emission reductions that will help achieve attainment of the national ambient air quality standard for ozone. This rule will be effective 3/23/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; New Mexico; Albuquerque/Bernalillo County; Prevention of significant deterioration (PSD) and new source review
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the SIP for the Albuquerque/Bernalillo County, NM, area that were submitted to EPA by the Governor of New Mexico on 5/24/2006. The proposed revisions modify the Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment New Source Review (NNSR) regulations in the SIP. They were submitted to make the area's PSD and NNSR rules consistent with Federal NNSR and PSD revised regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002 (67 Federal Register (FR) 80186) and reconsidered with minor changes on 11/7/2003 (68 FR 63021) (collectively, these Federal actions are called the 2002 New Source Review Reform Rules). The revisions include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected-actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plantwide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. EPA is proposing to approve these revisions pursuant to section 110, part C, and part D of the Federal Clean Air Act. Comments must be received on or before 3/19/2007. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, CO, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, SOx, VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer continental shelf air regulations consistency update for Alaska
Abstract: EPA is finalizing the updates of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations proposed in the Federal Register on 8/22/2006. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of States seaward boundaries must be updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area (COA), as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the Clean Air Act. The portion of the OCS air regulations that is being updated pertains to the requirements for OCS sources in the State of Alaska. The intended effect of approving the OCS requirements for the State of Alaska is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. The change to the existing requirements discussed is incorporated by reference into the Code of Federal Regulations and is listed in the appendix to the OCS air regulations. The subjects listed in 40 CFR Part 55 include environmental protection, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, NO2, NOx, O3, particulate matter, and SOx. This rule is effective on 3/12/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Fuels & lubes: Emulsion technology to cut APL emissions
Abstract: APL has partnered with the CARB, the EPA, the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, and four California air quality management boards, to test innovative fuel emulsification technology that could reduce NOx emissions from vessels by as much as 20% and become a shipping industry standard. APL and its partners will also test marine engine technologies, including slide valves and a next-generation lubricating system, that could further cut down on pollution from exhaust. Taken together, the initiatives are expected to have long-term air quality benefits for coastal communities by cutting down exhaust from ocean-going container shops. APL's approach to cleaner air includes a 3-yr demonstration project aboard the container ship APL Singapore that will be monitored by the University of California, Riverside. The project will test new technologies that are being installed on the vessel, including water-in-fuel emulsification, slide valves in the engine's cylinders, and a lubricating system. The demonstration project starts in February 2007 with initial test results expected about a month later.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Finsbury Green's river of gold
Abstract: Finsbury Green Printing company, Australia, is getting the National Print Awards for several years, for maintaining excellence in its service. Its was also awarded for its Cibo Ristorante Postcards, Urban Parks Info Pack, Heritage Range Brochure. Finsbury is the first Australian printer to gain simultaneous certification of ISO14001 and the first commercial printer to volunteer for the Federal Government's Greenhouse Challenge to reduce greenhouse gas emission. 99% of the ink used in Finsbury is vegetable based, 100 percent of its printing plates are digital, eliminating film and its associated chemicals and 95 percent of all waste material are recycled. Prepress and press facilities are connected by a CIP4 workflow, with prepress settings sent to the presses.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Progress on plug-ins
Abstract: Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEV), also called grid connected hybrids, are emerging as logical solutions for all kinds of hybrid vehicles. One important aspect of PHEV is that they can remove mobile emissions sources, gasoline and diesel engines, with stationary central power plant sources which are cleaner and easier to regulate. PHEVs shift stationary emissions from daylight hours to nighttime hours, thereby reducing the creation of ozone and smog. Genetal Motors plans to offer a Saturn Vue Green Line plug-in hybrid in 2008 that can double the fuel economy of any SUV and provide electric-only propulsion. DaimlerChrysler is placing Sprinter plug-in PHEVs to operate in Los Angeles, Kansas City, and New York and they will be tested in utility van and paratransit bus configurations. The external difference between the plug-in hybrid Sprinter and a conventional production van is the flap housing the socket for connecting the battery to a power source and charging it overnight.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: European commission wants greater energy efficiency
Abstract: The European Commision (EC) has prepared several proposals that intend to form a common European Union (EU) energy policy to improve energy supply in EU member countries and tackle issues of climate change, making energy industry more competitive in the region. The proposals include a reduction of 20% in carbon dioxide emissions by 2020, greater use of renewable energy resources to limit global temperature changes to 2°C higher than pre-industrial levels, and a 20% energy efficiency improvement. The European Commision has also proposed to develop a coordinated approach to energy issues and to introduce effective energy-sharing mechanisms to deal with future energy supply crises. The EC also wants the EU energy sector to become more competitive, with a proposed separation of energy production from distribution, as electricity and gas markets liberalize by 2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Cleaner, greener locomotives
Abstract: Manufacturers are using new technology switchers to meet the railroad needs as well as government requirements regarding environmental regulation. The network in urban rail yard is denser and it needs a stronger demand for air quality improvement. Union Pacific has acquired 60 National Railway Equipment Co. N-ViroMotion GenSet locomotives powered by three 700 hp ultra-low emissions diesel engines, which are designed to reduce particulate emission. The company is also using RailPower Technologies' green Goats with diesel-battery hybrid technology designed to cut air emissions by 80% and reduce diesel fuel by 40%. The Tier 3 proposals of the US environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have made guideline for the switchers. Norfolk Southern and CN have also been purchasing GE's 12-cylinder Evolution Series units, launched in 2005, which are achieving 5% fuel savings and reducing emissions by 40%-plus with the same 4,400 hp as the 16-cylinder predecessor.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: A winning combination
Abstract: M-real Hallein mill started its biomass-fired combined heat and power (CHP) plants to reduce operating energy costs of the Austrian LWC mills. The 30 MW plant provide about 20% of the mill's energy requirements. The CHP facility, which has a capacity of 33 tonnes steam/hr, can supply 21 MW of process heat and 4.84 MW of electricity to LWC mills. The plant require about 15 tonnes/hr raw materials, consisting of bark, wood, cores, sludges. The CHP facility provide the mill with residual heat and process steam and supplies district heat for 850 households via Salzburg's local grid. The CHP plant helps mill to reduce CO2 emissions by 33,000-45000 tonnes per year. The plant also enables the LWC mills to cut its natural gas use by 23 million Nm3.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Combined cycle power plants; Operating costs; Process steam; Residual heat; Paper and pulp mills; Biomass; Operating Costs; Paper Mills

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: EU ETS scheme may "fail to deliver"
Abstract: According to Datamonitor, EU's emissions trading scheme (EU ETS) "will ultimately fail to deliver in its current form", noting that an over-allocation of emissions credits in the first phase continues to subdue the price of carbon below the levels necessary to promote genuine investment in carbon abatement and, moreover, a lack of policy cohesion is consistently undermining Europe's attempt to get the second phase back on track. Unless Brussels gets to grip with this fledgling, but disparate market, the EU will collectively miss its Kyoto targets. The lack of collective political commitment among Member States will debilitate Brussels attempt to establish the necessary level of phase two quota cuts;. The second phase of emissions trading begins in January 2008 and ends in 2012 - by which time Europe is committed under the Kyoto Protocol to cut overall carbon emissions by 8% on 1990 levels.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State's rules: Delaware - Cleaning-up power plants
Abstract: The Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control recently promulgated regulations that will significantly reduce emissions from the state's largest coal and residual oil-burning electric generating units. The regulation will reduce emissions of SO2 by 87% and NOx by 76% by 2013, as well as requiring more than an 80% reduction of mercury emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Materials: Fibre matches strength of glass at one-third density
Abstract: US Patent 7 074 4 83 by Innegrity LLC of the United States covers a polypropylene (PP) fiber with a specific modulus and tensile strength close to glass fiber and a density of 0.9 g·cm3 as well as strength twice that of aramid. Although more expensive than glass fiber, the fiber is much lower than Kevlar and carbon. Composites featuring the fiber in conjunction with glass, aramid or carbon can show significant reductions in weight.
Index Keywords: glass fiber; patent; polypropylene fiber; strength; tensile property

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Michigan; Control of gasoline volatility
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Michigan on 5/26/2006, and 7/14/2006, establishing a lower Rvp fuel requirement for gasoline distributed in the Southeast Michigan area which includes Lenawee, Livingston, Macomb, Monroe, Oakland, St. Clair, Washtenaw, and Wayne Counties. The state has developed these fuel requirements to reduce emissions of VOC in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act. EPA is approving Michigan's fuel requirements into the Michigan SIP because EPA has found that the requirements are necessary for Southeast Michigan to achieve the 8-hr ozone NAAQS. On 8/15/2006, the EPA published a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking proposing to approve the SIP revision. During the comment period EPA received adverse comments from one commenter. This document summarizes the comments received, EPA's responses, and finalizes the approval of Michigan's SIP revision to establish a Rvp limit of 7 psi for gasoline sold in Southeast Michigan. This final rule is effective on 3/2/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Science & technology concentrates: Trackinig fossil fuel CO2 with corn
Abstract: A new study suggests that the distribution of fossil-fuel-produced CO2 in the lower atmosphere may be reflected in the tissues of annual plants, corn in particular. Fossil fuels contain no 14C, a trait that renders the CO2 produced when coal, oil, and gas are burned distinguishable from other atmospheric CO2 sources. Annual plants take in this CO2 during their growth cycle. In areas with higher fossil-fuel-derived CO2, carbon in the plant tissue contains relatively lower percentages of 14C. This allows scientists to monitor atmospheric composition over an entire season. With this in mind, James T. Randerson et al., of the University of California, Irvine, measured levels of 14C in corn plants in dozens of farmers' fields throughout North America and found a clear pattern: The Rocky Mountains, where 14C levels were highest, act as a barrier to fossil fuel CO2 migration across the US. Fossil fuel CO2 levels were higher in California and on the East Coast, particularly in states such as Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Wisconsin; Correction
Abstract: This document corrects an error in the Incorporation by Reference Section in a final rule pertaining to the 5/17/1999, approval of the State of Wisconsin's Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) rules. That rulemaking erroneously incorporated by reference a section of the Wisconsin Administrative Code dealing with the states hazardous pollutants rule. That section of the rule was not included in the states request for SIP approval of its PSD rules. EPA, therefore, is removing this provision from the SIP. The list of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes air pollution control, CO, and particulate matter. This final rule is effective on 1/18/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Siemens completes big CHP plant
Abstract: According to Siemens Power Generation, a new 260-Mw combined heat and power plant, the Rya project in Gothenburg, is the largest plant built in Sweden in 20 yr. The company built the natural gas-fired plant on a turnkey basis. It was formally commissioned late 2006. The plant's overall efficiency of 92.5% contributes to its saving 600,000 ton/yr of CO2 emissions. The CHP plant will meet about 35% of Gothenburg's district heating demands and 30% of its power needs. Siemens PG provided all civil works, turbines, a single heat-recovery steam generator, erection, commissioning, and performance test. The company will also be responsible for servicing the plant for 15 yr. Three 45-Mw SGT-800 gas turbines and one 141-Mw SST-900 steam turbine anchor the power island. The gas turbines are specially designed for the 3 × 1 × 1 configuration and equipped with low-NOx burners that can handle gas or fuel oil.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Practical aspects of burning landfill gas
Abstract: Landfill gas is a renewable fuel with a heating value of 350 to 600 Btu/cu ft, about 50% that of natural gas. Early repowering projects included installing either reciprocating engines or small gas turbines to burn the landfill gas. That was done more to solve an environmental problem than to capture the power. As it turns out, methane leakage from urban landfills that lack methane collection remediation often is problematic for neighbors of the plant and/or the landfill. Using compressors made of exotic alloys solved that problem but ruined project economics. Larger landfill gas power plants, such as the 48-Mw Puente Hills project operated by the Los Angeles County Sanitation District (LACSD), have succeeded by taking a low-risk approach to reducing methane leakage. The gas collection system at Puente Hills uses > 1000 wells, 55 mi of underground trenches, and > 30 mi of pipes to collect an average of 26,000 cu ft/min of landfill gas. The plant's overall heat rate is about 11,000 Btu/kw-hr. LACSD also compresses landfill gas for use by the facility's water trucks and passenger vehicles, saving the equivalent of 1000 gal/day of diesel fuel. According to the EPA's Landfill Methane Outreach Program, > 70 steam plants have switched their boiler fuel to landfill gas and enjoy from 10% to 40% fuel savings as their reward. The plants' fuel demand ranges from 2 to 150 mmBtu/hr. The lower flame temperatures produced when landfill gas burns generate lower levels of NOx emissions than natural gas, but operating at these temperatures may require increasing the surface area of the superheater.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: National emission standards for hazardous air pollutants for source categories from oil and natural gas production facilities
Abstract: This action promulgates national emission standards for hazardous air pollutants to regulate hazardous air pollutant emissions from oil and natural gas production facilities that are area sources. The final national emission standards for hazardous air pollutants for major sources was promulgated on 6/17/99, but final action with respect to area sources was deferred. Oil and natural gas production is identified in the Urban Air Toxics Strategy as an area source category for regulation under section 112(c)(3) of the Clean Air Act because of benzene emissions from triethylene glycol dehydration units located at such facilities. This final rule also amends a general provision in the regulation to allow the use of an ASTM standard as an alternative test method to EPA Method 18 in the National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants From Oil and Natural Gas Production Facilities. This final rule is effective on 1/3/2007. The incorporation by reference of certain publications listed in these rules is approved by the Director of the Federal Register as of 1/3/2007. The entities likely regulated by this action include condensate tank batteries, glycol dehydration units, and natural gas processing plants.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: US: Bush unveils energy-policy make-over
Abstract: According to US President George Bush, the country must reduce gasoline consumption by 20% by 2017 to reduce its dependence on oil. Plans outlined in the annual State of the Union address are to achieve the reduction by increasing use of alternative fuels, especially ethanol, and by raising fuel-economy standards for cars. However, analysts say the plan is unrealistic. This is partly because the technology for certain types of biofuels will not be ready for several years and also because of a lack of sufficient ethanol-transport infrastructure exists. Land availability is another problem: according to a study by the University of Minnesota, nearly 15% of corn grown in the US is converted to ethanol, but this replaces less than 2% of gasoline usage. In addition, ethanol will not necessarily reduce carbon emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Iraq prepares oil law
Abstract: Iraq's oil ministry officials were finalizing the country's draft hydrocarbons law. The draft law, amended from a version that was put to the State Oil Committee in August 2006, will set out a new type of agreement, replacing production-sharing contracts (PSC). PSC are seen by many Iraqis as a model that will enable foreign companies to plunder the country's 115 billion bbl of oil reserves, so the new contracts are expected to be branded as development and production contracts. Under the new draft law, control over contract awards, oil revenues and the distribution of oil receipts to the regions would be centralized. A federal committee will be established, chaired by the prime minister, to oversee contracts, including those granted by the Kurdistan Regional Government. The draft hydrocarbons law will also call for the re-establishment of a national oil company, Iraq National Oil Corp.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State's rules: Maryland: Cruisin' like California
Abstract: Maryland is well on its way to becoming the 12th state to adopt regulatory controls for CO2 emissions from cars. The House of Delegates approved the Maryland Clean Cars Act and the Senate is posed to do the same. HB 131 and the companion SB 103 would require that the Maryland Department of the Environment, in consultation with the Motor Vehicle Commission, establish regulations for a low emissions vehicle program starting with model year 2011. The bill authorizes the department to adopt California regulations by reference.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Canada: Cow waste processor puts gas in pipeline
Abstract: Quest Air Technologies has installed one of its methane purifiers, M-3200 system, to convert methane generated from animal waste to pipeline-grade natural gas at the Scenic View Dairy in Fennville, MI. The project, the first of its kind in the US, is expected to generate enough energy to meet the needs of between 100 and 200 homes. In the process, the waste material is fed into an anaerobic digester; Quest Air's unit then purifies the methane produced by the digester. The methane produced by the plant is now being injected into the local natural gas distribution grid operated by Michigan Gas Utilities. More than 1.4 billion ton/yr of manure and other organic wastes are produced by the agricultural industry in the US. Such systems as the one used in Michigan offer the potential not only to produce renewable energy from these wastes, but also to produce environmentally-friendly organic fertilizers that can be reused in the agricultural sector. Each cow typically produces about 1 cu m/day of methane gas which, translates into one cow producing about 900 kw-hr/yr of electricity - or about 5-10% of the power used by a typical home annually. The system at Scenic View Dairy will generate about 350 cu ft/min of biogas, or about 13 million Btu/hr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Contracts: New F-T plant for China
Abstract: A new generation Fischer-Tropsch plant will be constructed in Shaanxi, China, by April 2007. Headed by a team of researchers from the Centre of Material and Process Synthesis (COMPS) at the University of Witwatersand, South Africa, the $10.4 million project will convert CO and H2 into liquid hydrocarbons. This pilot plant is predicted to be some 30% more efficient than current available technology. It will use gas from a nearby ammonia plant and coal from local reserves. After 6 mo, the pilot plant can be scaled up to commercial capacity.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Sasol's efforts to green CTL
Abstract: Sasol is planning to incorporate a new process consuming coal fines rather than coarse coal in the expansion of its coal-to-liquids (CTL) plant at Secunda, south Africa. The coal fines process will form part of a 30,000 bpd expansion of Sasol's Secunda, which will boost the complex capacity to 180,000 bpd. Coal fines will contribute 7500 bpd to the plant's output. The Secunda expansion will also include a 300 Mw cogeneration unit, which according to Sasol will reduce the amount of gas flared at Secunda while covering some of the plant's 1200 Mw power consumption, and a R4.5 billion program to decrease greenhouse gas emissions from Secunda by 10% from 2004 figures by 2015. As part of this program, Sasol has invested in N2O abatement at its two nitric acid plants based at Sasolburg and Secunda, using a secondary catalyst to convert N2O into nitrogen and oxygen. Meanwhile, Sasol is studying sites for a separate 80,000 bpd Greenfield CTL project, named "Project Mafutha". The plant is planned for an inland site, either in the Free State or Waterberg, and will help south Africa be more self-sufficient in transport fuels.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry news: Automaker pledges CO2 reductions
Abstract: GM had set a goal to reduce CO2 emissions from its US manufacturing operations by 40% by 2010. The auto manufacturer previously surpassed an announced goal of reducing such emissions by 10% by 2005. This was accomplished by increased use of solar power, seen on the roof of the GM Service Parts Operations Parts Distribution Center in Rancho Cucamonga, CA, and through a focus on energy conservation programs such as were demonstrated at the company's new Lansing Delta Township assembly plant in Lansing, MI, which earned LEED Gold recognition for green building designs in 2006. The company would seek to meet the new goals through such projects as improving energy efficiencies, reducing waste, and increasing the use of renewable resources such as landfill gas and solar power.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Acumentrics exhibits micro-CHP at Hannover
Abstract: Acumentrics exhibited a solid oxide fuel cell, home energy combined heat and power (CHP) appliance at the recent Hannover Fair in Germany. The company's AHEAD micro-CHP generates heat and electricity directly from natural gas or propane. The device provides 1 kw nominal, 2.5 kw peak enough electricity to power the average home, with peaks being handled by the grid or batteries. Electricity is created electrochemically in an array of solid state tubes. This system captures excess energy from the hot fuel cells, and supplements peak thermal loads with a clean, high efficiency burner, to provide up to 24 kw of thermal output. Compared with conventional technologies, CO2 emissions are significantly reduced through high conversion efficiencies.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Connecticut to fund state fuel cell projects
Abstract: The Connecticut Clean Energy Fund has screened and selected seven energy projects, incorporating 69 Mw of fuel cell power generation. Six of the projects will utilize Direct FuelCell molten carbonate power plants manufactured by FuelCell Energy in Danbury, with the other installation featuring a phosphoric acid fuel cell unit from UTC Power in South Windsor. The specific projects selected by CCEF include a 7.9 Mw DFC-ERG™ project that pairs 7.2 Mw of DirectFuel Cell units with a 1.5 Mw pipeline turbo expander; two 19.6 Mw projects for southwestern Connecticut, each consisting of eight DFC power plant units incorporating organic Rankine cycles to convert excess thermal energy from the fuel cells to deliver additional electrical output; and two projects, with the first a 4.6 Mw project for Stamford Hospital using two DFC3000 units in a cogeneration application to provide lower-cost thermal energy to the hospital as well as clean electricity to the grid. The other fuel cell project is a 1 Mw installation by UTC Power in Wallingford.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: FCE unit to use waste process gas in San Fran
Abstract: The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission (SFPUC) has approved an agreement to design, permit, and build the city's first fuel cell project at SFPUC's Southeast Wastewater Treatment Plant. Scheduled for completion by the end of 2007, the fuel cell, which will be manufactured by FuelCell Energy will convert gases, naturally generated within the wastewater treatment process, into electricity for use by the plant. The process will also reduce the facility's need to flare or burn the waste gas, significantly reducing emissions in the neighborhood. Otto H. Rosentreter Company and Alliance power will form a partnership to design and build a $2.2 million, 600 kw molten carbonate fuel cell, energy-generating plant at the facility, with a 5-yr operating and maintenance agreement. The project is being financed by the citys renewable energy project special funds and SFPUCs Power Enterprise operating funds.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: CO2 increase could reduce carbon in soil
Abstract: Researchers at the US Smithsonian Environmental Research Center have reported the results of a 6-yr experiment in which doubling the atmospheric greenhouse gas CO2 in a scrub oak ecosystem caused a reduction in carbon storage in the soil. These findings add a new perspective on the capacity of Earth's soils to store carbon. They suggest that elevated CO2, by altering microbial communities, may turn the soil from a potential carbon sink into a carbon source. This could offset some of the gains in carbon storage in plant biomass due to increased growth at elevated CO2. The scientists now need to consider a third possibility: the carbon already in soils will end up back in the atmosphere as a greenhouse gas.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Fuel Cell Application Facility launched in UK
Abstract: The Centre for Process Innovation on Teesside has established the UK's first independent Fuel Cell System Development Centre. The venture is a public access facility for regional companies involved in commercializing fuel cell technology, and will support the development of a strong regional industrial fuel cell cluster based around the Tees Valley, with its extensive production and infrastructure for all types of fuels, including hydrogen. It is working with local industrial partners to develop new product concepts, and open up new emerging markets where the high capital cost is offset by the lower day-to-day operating cost and the significant reduction in emissions. The FCAF Development Centre allows companies such as Cellspace to develop and test systems up to 5 kwe. The FCAF Development Centre plans to demonstrate fuel cell systems in transport, low-carbon buildings, and off-grid applications such as traffic signs where there is no electrical supply. The region is developing what it claims is Europes first Hydrogen Network, a 20 mi integrated system that pipes hydrogen throughout the Tees Valley area of North East England.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: NYSERDA funds aid SOFC insulation program
Abstract: The New York State Energy Research and Development Authority has awarded a contract to ENrG Inc for up to $0.5 million to support the development of an "advanced insulation" for solid oxide fuel cell power units. ENrG has developed technology to enhance the insulation package for SOFC power units, enabling system integrators to further reduce the mass and size of their systems. The company is leading this $1.3 million project, with testing support provided by Delphi Corp. By cogenerating power on-site at industrial facilities, commercial businesses or even residences, the co-product heat produced by a SOFC electrical power-generating system allows combined heat and electrical power (CHP) systems to run at 90% efficiency. Similarly, while parked, heavy-duty trucks will be able to use SOFC auxiliary systems to generate both heat and electric power, saving up to 85% of the fuel that they currently consume when their main engine is idling, and significantly reducing emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: FCE unit to power California wastewater treatment facility
Abstract: FuelCell Energy has sold a DFC1500MA power plant to operate on anaerobic digester gas from a sewage treatment facility serving the southern California city of Riverside. The facility treats 30 million gal/day of wastewater. The Direct FuelCell® plant was sold through FCE's distributor, Alliance Power Inc. Renewable fuel for the DFC1500MA power plant will come from gas generated in the wastewater treatment process. This digester gas has until now been used by three reciprocating engines that power the treatment plant.
