The use of fuel cells will significantly reduce nitrogen oxides, particulates and sulfur oxides. The DFC unit will also reduce the rate of CO2 emitted for each kw-hr generated.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EPA proposes first OBD rules for trucks... California cracks down on small gasoline engines... AGCO OKs biodiesel
Abstract: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is proposing the new monitoring requirements for the emissions control systems of large diesel and gasoline trucks and buses by the onboard diagnostic (OBD) systems. The proposed regulation will ensure that emissions control systems in vehicles over 14,000 lb work properly for the useful life of the vehicle. This requirement is expected to affect 2010 and later model year vehicles. EPA is also seeking comment on possible future regulations that would require OBD systems on heavy-duty diesel engines used in nonroad equipment. The EPA has granted California a disclaimer allowing the state to require the use of catalytic aftertreatment systems on small gasoline engines used in lawn mowers and other small equipment. AGCO Corp. has approved a broad range of biodiesel mixtures for its SisuDiesel engines. Biodiesel as the only alternative fuel for SisuDiesel engines, must conform to the European norm EN 14214 or the US norm ASTM D6751.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Sign's green credentials
Abstract: About 100 local authorities around the UK are using the innovative and energy saving Traffic Management Product's (TMP) Flecta passive safety sign. Flecta is highly visible traffic sign, requiring no external power supply. The local authorities uses the TMP Flecta to save energy and money, and make maintenance and repair conditions safer for the roadside workers. The TMP Flecta is revolutionary retro-reflective passive sign which springs back upon impact. Flecta is used for a variety of reasons across the country, such as saving energy, decrease carbon emission, reduce light pollution, and reduce traffic disruption. Flecta is designed to withstand and absorb impacts of up to 45mph with its Impact Recovery System (IRS). Flecta also benefits from its innovative anti-twist mechanism which ensures correct realignment with traffic following a collision.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Report from FiO: Global issues, optics solutions
Abstract: Speakers at the 2006 Frontiers in Optics (FiO) conference discussed some challenges faced by the optics community to solve some problems, which include the need to find alternative energy sources that halt progression of Alzheimer's disease. LBL researchers developed the technology that made compact fluorescent lights and infrared-reflecting windows commercially feasible. Government must enact a carbon tax to reverse the cost advantage to releasing greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. LBL has also proposed a project called Helios that would pursue new methods such as nanotechnology to convert sunlight into carbon-neutral energy sources. Quasi-elastic infrared light scattering is a non-invasive technique that helps in identifying the peptide so that physicians can treat Alzheimer's patients at a much earlier stage. Researchers have developed a opthalmoscope, which could improve the diagnosis of retinal disease.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Vehicle emissions case promises broad impact
Abstract: The US Supreme Court's ruling is expected to affect voluntary efforts of the environmental groups to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The Supreme court started hearing arguments raised by several environmental groups against the refusal by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to regulate the amount of carbon dioxide emitted from vehicles. The Court's ruling is awaited with much interest by the chemical industry and the automobile manufacturers. If the ruling goes against the EPA, then the efforts to control carbon dioxide emissions could hinge on federal regulation rather than the voluntary reduction. Washington D.C., Nature Works researched a number of alternative energy sources before opting to buy RECs from a variety of power projects in the Midwest. Many states and environmentalists have started filing suits to pressure the government to implement a federal GHG emissions control program.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Update: Environmental: California hopes to lead GHG initiative
Abstract: California became the first state to approve mandatory greenhouse gas emission caps that include penalties for non-compliance for all major industries. The Democrat-controlled Legislature reached a consensus with Republican Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger on a measure capping greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions at 1990 levels by 2020, representing a nearly 25% reduction in emissions. The state plans to implement a cap-and-trade program for refineries, utilities, and manufacturing plants. The California Chamber of Commerce, which expressed concern over the bill's economic impact, is calling for the creation of tax credits for businesses, to spur earlier adoption of more-efficient systems for generating and conserving energy.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: HPInnovations: Renewable energy and chemicals unit formed
Abstract: UOP LLC has established a new business unit, Renewable Energy and Chemicals. The unit is planned to accelerate efforts to develop renewable energy technologies that are based on the company's petroleum processes and will convert biofeedstocks, such as vegetable oils, greases and certain waste products, into fuel and chemicals. Production of biofuels such as ethanol and biodiesel is expanding. Significant factors include the continued rising cost of petroleum, availability of local energy sources, commitment to reduce greenhouse gases, and government mandates and incentives. UOP's development efforts are focusing on production of biobased transportation fuels that can be used with existing diesel and gasoline fuel infrastructures. UOP collaborated on this project with DOE's National Renewable Energy Laboratory (PNNL), and the Pacific Northwest National Lab. Separately, the company teamed with PNNL in 2004 to deliver technology for upgrading glycerol, a byproduct from converting vegetable oil into biodiesel, into higher value propylene glycol. The new business unit also plans to identify and evaluate technologies for refineries that use other renewable energy sources.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Climate change: Can regional, state, and voluntary approaches do the job?
Abstract: Climate change - Can state, regional, and voluntary approaches do the job? The Institute brought together six prominent players in the global warming debate to defend their views about where the responsibility lies for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and who is in the best position to act, during the annual ELI-Miriam Hamilton Keare Policy Forum.
Index Keywords: climate change; environmental policy; global warming; greenhouse gas; regional planning; state role; voluntary approach

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Latest developments from the EU
Abstract: Recent EU oil and gas news are presented, including the first 10 national CO2 emission allocation plans for EU Member States released by the European Commission; the EC's plan release a "communication" in January 2007 on significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions over the next few decades; analysis at the Commission of the EU's Euro 5 and 6 fuel and engine emissions standards; and European Investment Banks plan to lend Italy's ENEL Produzione up to €400 million to convert two oil-fired power plants into gas-fired combined cycle gas turbine units.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: New contracts: Clean Diesel Technology...
Abstract: Clean Diesel Technology is now expanding its European distributor network in the Nordic countries and Baltic states. The company develops technological solutions to reduce harmful engine emissions and has signed a distribution agreement with Broste.
